summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's defense requests. The government argues against disclosing witness names 11 months before trial and against court intervention in her detention conditions at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC). It details the discovery production timeline and disputes defense claims of inadequate access.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330). The government is opposing her defense team's requests for early witness disclosure and intervention in her detention conditions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The presiding judge in the case. The government's letter is addressed to her, requesting she deny the defendant's applications.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The signatory of the government's opposition letter, submitting it on behalf of the U.S. Attorney's Office.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Maxwell.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against Maxwell.

events.title: Initial Discovery Production
events.description: The Government produced an initial discovery batch totaling more than 12,000 pages to the defense.

events.title: Second Discovery Production
events.description: The Government made a second discovery production totaling more than 150,000 pages, principally consisting of financial records.

events.title: Protective Order Docketed
events.description: The protective order governing discovery in the case was posted to the court docket, following the defendant's initial refusal to agree to its terms.

events.title: Maxwell Receives First Discovery Batch
events.description: The defendant received her personal copy of the Government's first discovery production at the Metropolitan Detention Center.

events.title: Scheduled Trial
events.description: The trial is scheduled for July 2021, approximately 11 months from the date of this filing.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government had produced over 165,000 pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense within two weeks of the protective order being entered.
The government strongly opposed disclosing the names of victim-witnesses 11 months before trial, citing a desire to protect victim privacy and a lack of legal precedent for such early disclosure.
The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) planned to provide Maxwell extended access to discovery materials from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. daily, contrary to defense claims of limited access.

The government accused Maxwell's defense counsel of attempting to use sealed criminal discovery materials in parallel civil litigation, referencing a public filing in case 'Ghislaine Maxwell, No. 15 Civ. 7433 (LAP)'.

The Superseding Indictment describes relevant time periods, events, conversations with victims, interactions with victims, and specific locations, which the government argued provided adequate notice of the charges.
